If the OS platform does not record the required auditable records, logging must be performed through the syslog subsystem. If logging is performed through syslog, the LogLevel must be set to INFO or higher.  Must be set to VERBOSE or higher if multiple keys are used to access shared IDs.
If any DEBUG level is specified, the resultant log files must be accessible only by the superuser (e.g. root or administrator) account in order to maintain privacy of user data.

May be set to "forced-commands-only"  or "without-password" only if mechanisms are in place to determine the identity of the individual accessing the system.
Otherwise, must be set to "no".

Parameter:
PermitRootLogin forced-commands
PermitRootLogin without-password
PermitRootLogin yes
Inicial Value: If public-key authentication is used to access the root account, separate private keys must be used for each individual and logs must be maintained showing which individuals have accessed the root account.

Keys used for authentication must meet the required bit length value for public key algorithms specified in the acceptable public key algorithms listed here: http://w3.the.ibm.com/ecmweb/cybersecurity/acceptable_algorithms.html

The key pairs do not need to be updated periodically. However, if the private key is suspected to have been compromised, the public and private keys must be regenerated.

If public-key authentication is configured on a shared user account, separate private keys must be used for each individual and logs must be maintained showing which individuals have accessed the account.
Must not be used to enable host-based authentication.

SSL / OpenSSL: If SSH protocol version 1 is enabled, ServerKeyBits option must be set to a value equal or greater to the required bit length value for public key algorithms specified in the acceptable algorithms listed here: http://w3.the.ibm.com/ecmweb/cybersecurity/acceptable_algorithms.html

Parameter: Data Transmission - All native encryption ciphers
Inicial Value: Must meet the minimum bit length value specified in the acceptable encryption ciphers listed here: http://w3.the.ibm.com/ecmweb/cybersecurity/acceptable_algorithms.html
The DES algorithm uses 56-bit keys and is relatively easy to compromise. Therefore it must not be used.
